sentences: Oswald George Nelson (March 20, 1906 – June 3, 1975) was an American  actor, director, producer, screenwriter, musician, composer, conductor and bandleader.
Nelson was born March 20, 1906 in Jersey City, New Jersey, United States.
He played football at Ridgefield Park High School as well as during his college years at Rutgers University.
He graduated from Rutgers University with a bachelor's degree and earned a law degree from Rutgers School of Law, Newark, New Jersey, in 1930.
Nelson was made a doctor of humane letters by Rutgers University in 1957.
Nelson was not discouraged and was gracious about this rejection when he met Ades years later.
Nelson made his own "big break" in 1930, when The New York Daily Mirror ran a poll of its readers to determine their favorite band.

In 1998, A&E broadcast a documentary entitled Ozzie and Harriet: The Adventures of America's Favorite Family, which depicted Ozzie Nelson as a dictatorial personality who "thwarted his sons, preventing them from attending college and reminding them that they were obliged to work on television".
In 1973, Ozzie Nelson published his autobiography, Ozzie, (Prentice Hall, 1973, ISBN 0-13-647768-2).

Nelson suffered from recurring malignant tumors in his later years, and eventually succumbed to liver cancer.
He died at his home in the San Fernando Valley on June 3, 1975, with his wife and sons at his bedside.
Services were held at the Church of the Hills at Forest Lawn, Hollywood Hills, California on Friday, June 6.
When his elder son David died in 2011, he was cremated, having chosen a niche in Westwood Memorial Park's outdoor Garden of Serenity columbarium rather than interment in the Nelson family plot.
